It's not 100+ miles of cable, it's 26,000 miles.
 
 For those not familiar with space elevators, they work (in theory) like this. Get a space platform in geosynchronous orbit. That means it stays over the same spot on the equator, about 26,000 miles up. From the platform you lower a cable all the way to the earth. Hook some elevator cars to the cable, run them with solar power collected from the sattelite, an voila, you can get into orbit for almost free.
 
 The reason the cable doesn't pull the platfrom down out of orbit is that while you're lowering the cable, you extend a massive weight out away from earth. Things in geosynchromous orbit have the neat property that if you give them a small push towards earth they'll spiral in, but if you give them a small push away from earth they'll escape earth's orbit. Thus, the cable will pull down, and the mass will pull out (up?) and by adjusting how far out you extend the mass you can get the two forces to balance.
 
 The main problem here, aside from cost, is finding a material strong enough to make a 26,000 mile cable from. Nano-tubes look promising, but many people, like me, think we have a ways to go before they're viable.
